clean_content:
Definition / general

* Grossly visible noninvasive mucinous epithelial neoplasm arising from main pancreatic duct or branch ducts, usually > 5 mm, composed of various cell types with various cytologic and architectural atypia ([Virchows Arch 2005;447:794](16088402), [Pancreatology 2017;17:738](28735806))
  + Further classified as:
    - Low grade (encompasses low or intermediate grade dysplasia) ([Am J Surg Pathol 2015;39:1730](26559377))- High grade ([Am J Surg Pathol 2015;39:1730](26559377))- With an associated invasive carcinoma ([Am J Surg Pathol 2015;39:1730](26559377))* 1 of 3 precursor lesions of pancreatic adenocarcinoma (see also [mucinous cystic neoplasm](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasmcn.html))

Essential features

* Grossly visible (> 5 mm) cystic pancreatic neoplasm, usually in head of pancreas* > 90% 5 year survival with complete resection* Roughly 33% of cases have an associated invasive carcinoma* Further subtyped into gastric, intestinal and pancreaticobiliary types based on epithelium (note: [intraductal oncocytic papillary neoplasm (IOPN)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasiopn.html) is now considered a distinct and separate entity)

Terminology

* Low grade to intermediate grade dysplasia previously termed: intraductal papillary mucinous adenoma* High grade dysplasia previously termed: intraductal papillary mucinous carcinoma, noninvasive* With an associated invasive carcinoma previously termed: intraductal papillary mucinous carcinoma, invasive* Other previous terms include: mucin producing tumor, mucinous duct ectasia, ductectatic mucinous cystadenoma / cystadenocarcinoma, villous adenoma or papillary adenoma / carcinoma

ICD coding

* ICD-10: [D13.6](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/D10-D36/D13-/D13.6) - benign neoplasm of pancreas

Epidemiology

* Rising incidence likely secondary to better characterization of this entity along with use of radiologic imaging studies ([Clin Gastroenterol Hepatol 2010;8:213](19835989))* More common in men, usually ages 60 - 70 years ([Hum Pathol 2012;43:1](21777948))

Sites

* Main duct intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN) mostly involves head of pancreas, 33% in body and tail ([Hum Pathol 2012;43:1](21777948))* Branch duct IPMN mostly involves head of pancreas or uncinate process, with multiple distinct lesions seen in ~33% of cases ([Hum Pathol 2012;43:1](21777948))

Pathophysiology

* See [Molecular / cytogenetics description](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasipmn.html#pancreasipmnmolec)

Etiology

* No well established factors; cigarette smoking implicated in one series ([Adv Anat Pathol 1999;6:65](10331069))* Reported in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome and familial adenomatous polyposis ([Gut 2002;51:446](12171972), [Am J Pathol 1999;154:1835](10362809))

Diagrams / tables

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasipmn_nih04.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6117658/figure/F2/)

Indications for surgery

Clinical features

* Clinically divided into main duct IPMN, branch duct IPMN and mixed IPMN (most mixed type IPMN present and behave as main duct IPMN) ([Hum Pathol 2012;43:1](21777948))* Main duct IPMN tends to be symptomatic, with symptoms related to duct obstruction (pancreatitis) ([Hum Pathol 2012;43:1](21777948))
    + Signs and symptoms include epigastric pain, weight loss, jaundice, diabetes, pancreatitis ([Arch Pathol Lab Med 1996;120:981](12046614))* Branch duct IPMN tends to be asymptomatic and is generally discovered incidentally on imaging ([Hum Pathol 2012;43:1](21777948))* [Peutz-Jeghers syndrome](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/colontumorPeutz.html) (autosomal dominant inherited syndrome, mutations in *STK11* / *LKB1I*) is also associated with IPMN ([Hum Pathol 2012;43:1](21777948))

Diagnosis

* Radiographic / endoscopic findings* Fine needle aspiration* Surgical specimen

Laboratory

* Pancreatic cyst fluid analysis can assist in determining type of cyst ([Am J Gastroenterol 2008;103:2871](18775021), [Gastrointest Endosc 2009;69:1095](19152896), [Gastrointest Endosc 2016;83:140](26253016))
  + Elevated CEA and identification of *KRAS / GNAS* mutations supports diagnosis of mucinous cyst

Radiology description

* CT:
  + Main duct IPMN causes distention of main pancreatic duct+ Branch duct IPMN produces multilocular grape-like cystic appearance* ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography): pancreatic ductal filling defects may be seen / ductal dilation* MRCP (magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography): additional imaging option which does not produce radiation* EUS (endoscopic ultrasound): can also allow FNA and cyst fluid analysis* References: [Diagn Interv Imaging 2016;97:1275](27840080), [World J Gastroenterol 2016;22:9562](27920477)

Radiology images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasipmnradio1.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/core/lw/2.0/html/tileshop_pmc/tileshop_pmc_inline.html?title=Click%20on%20image%20to%20zoom&p=PMC3&id=5429895_12328_2017_728_Fig1_HTML.jpg)
 
[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasipmnradio2.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5116600/figure/F2/)
 
[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasipmnradio6.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5546617/figure/F2/)

MRCP demonstrating various types of IPMN

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasipmnradio7.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5546617/figure/F3/)

MRCP demonstrating side branch IPMNs

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasipmnradio5.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3135334/figure/F1/)

Differing radiologic  
modalities demonstrating  
various types of  
IPMN and MCN

Prognostic factors

* Without an invasive carcinoma, has > 90% 5 year survival; those associated with an invasive carcinoma carry a worse prognosis (about half die of the disease) ([Ann Surg 2016;263:162](25775066))* Main duct IPMN: 60% have high grade dysplasia and 45% are associated with an invasive carcinoma ([Hum Pathol 2012;43:1](21777948))* Branch duct IPMN: most are low grade, 25% have high grade dysplasia and 20% are associated with an invasive carcinoma ([Hum Pathol 2012;43:1](21777948))* Invasive carcinoma associated with IPMN includes:
        + Tubular (ductal) adenocarcinoma: seen in about half of cases, with slightly better prognosis than non IPMN associated pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma+ Colloid carcinoma: seen in half of cases, with much better prognosis than pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma ([Ann Surg 2016;263:162](25775066))

Case reports

* 52 year old man with recurrent upper abdominal pain ([Int J Clin Exp Med 2015;8:3332](26064223))* 53 year old man with multiple pancreatic cystic lesions ([World J Gastroenterol 2013;19:3358](23745041))* 55 year old woman with abdominal pain and anemia; pancreatic masses are found on CT ([World J Surg Oncol 2018;16:83](29690869))* 68 year old man with cystic pancreatic mass with mural nodule ([Int J Surg Case Rep 2017;40:69](28942226))* 74 year old man with cystic pancreatic lesion on ultrasound ([Intern Med 2018;57:1093](29269677))

Treatment

* Main duct IPMN: surgical resection indicated if main pancreatic duct > 10 mm, jaundice or presence of mural nodules ([Pancreatology 2017;17:738](28735806))
  + Branch duct IPMN: surgical resection indicated if symptomatic, presence of mural nodule ≥ 5 mm, suspicious / positive cytology, obstructive jaundice or main pancreatic duct ≥ 10 mm ([Pancreatology 2017;17:738](28735806))+ See [Diagrams / tables](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasipmn.html#pancreasipmndiagrams)

Clinical images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasipmnnih01.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6035910/figure/fig0010/)

Mucin extrusion from duodenal papilla

Gross description

* Main duct involvement:
  + Usually diffusely dilated, tortuous and irregular, filled with mucin+ Typically arises in head and progresses along path of main duct, may involve entire pancreas; may involve major or minor papillae leading to mucin extrusion from ampulla+ Uninvolved pancreas is often pale and firm, reflecting extensive chronic obstructive pancreatitis* Branch duct involvement:
    + Often in uncinate process+ Forms multicystic, grape-like structures; cystically dilated ducts, filled with tenacious mucin; cyst walls are usually thin with flat or papillary lining+ Cysts separated by normal pancreas, suggesting that cysts are separate on cut sections* Multicentricity seen in up to 40% of cases ([Am J Gastroenterol 2007;102:1759](17686073))* Extensive sampling / complete submission of cyst for microscopic evaluation important to rule out an associated invasive carcinoma ([Am J Surg Pathol 2014;38:480](24451278), [Ann Surg 2016;263:162](25775066))* Greater than 5 mm in diameter
          + Incipient IPMN is a term that can be used for lesions 0.5 - 1.0 cm in size

Gross images

*Contributed by Dennis R. Dening, PA (ASCP), Wei Chen, M.D., Ph.D. and Nakul Anush Ravish, M.B.B.S.*  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasipmn_Agostini03.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasipmn_Agostini03.jpg)

Main duct IPMN

[![IPMN](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreascysticfluidanalysisChenRavish04.jpeg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreascysticfluidanalysisChenRavish04.jpeg)

IPMN

Frozen section description

* Typically pancreatic resection margin status will be evaluated to exclude IPMN; additional margins will be submitted if invasive carcinoma is present or possibly for the presence of high grade dysplasia ([Am J Surg Pathol 2015;39:1730](26559377), [Pancreatology 2017;17:738](28735806))* If low grade dysplasia is seen, typically no additional resection done; this may represent pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN) versus IPMN ([Am J Surg Pathol 2015;39:1730](26559377), [Pancreatology 2017;17:738](28735806))

Frozen section images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasipmn_nih02.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2999199/figure/F2/)

Normal pancreatic duct

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasipmn_nih03.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2999199/figure/F3/)

Pancreatic duct with low grade dysplasia

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Mucin producing epithelial cells with varied degrees of dysplasia ([Am J Surg Pathol 2015;39:1730](26559377))
  + Low grade dysplasia is characterized by a flat epithelial lining with basal located nuclei without significant pleomorphism, while intermediate dysplasia has features between those of low and high grade dysplasia (note: low and intermediate dysplasia are now both grouped as low grade dysplasia) ([Am J Surg Pathol 2015;39:1730](26559377))+ High grade dysplasia is characterized by complex architectural features (i.e. irregular branching, cribiforming) with loss of nuclear polarity along with increased nuclear hyperchromasia and nuclear irregularities ([Am J Surg Pathol 2015;39:1730](26559377))* Epithelial cells show variable differentiation and can be subclassified into: intestinal, gastric and pancreaticobiliary subtypes (oncocytic lining suggests intraductal oncocytic papillary neoplasm)* Associated with pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN), chronic pancreatitis ([Am J Surg Pathol 2004;28:1184](15316318))* No ovarian type stroma* Assess presence or absence of invasive carcinoma (most important prognostic factor) ([Hum Pathol 2012;43:1](21777948))* Type of invasion is associated with MUC1 / MUC2 pattern; see [below](https://pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasipmn.html#pancreasipmnpositivestainRB) ([Mod Pathol 2002;15:1087](12379756))* Gastric type IPMN:
              + Cells resemble gastric foveolae+ Intestinal metaplasia may be seen, usually with low grade dysplasia and branch duct IPMN+ If associated invasive carcinoma present, typically ductal (tubular) adenocarcinoma ([Ann Surg 2016;263:162](25775066), [Virchows Arch 2005;447:794](16088402))* Intestinal type IPMN:
                + Cells with tall columnar epithelium (resembling intestinal villous adenomas)+ Usually low or high grade dysplasia and main duct IPMN+ If associated invasive carcinoma present, typically mucinous (colloid) carcinoma* Pancreaticobiliary type IPMN:
                  + Complex, thin branching papillae resembling cholangiopapillary neoplasms+ Cuboidal cells with prominent nucleoli+ Usually high grade dysplasia and main duct IPMN+ If associated invasive carcinoma present, typically ductal (tubular) adenocarcinoma

Microscopic (histologic) images

Virtual slides

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasipmn_utoronto04.png)](http://dlm.lmp.utoronto.ca/image/pancreas-intraductal-papillary-mucinous-neoplasm-ipmn-non-invasive-lmp42662)

IPMN, low grade, intestinal type

Cytology description

* Cannot distinguish IPMN from mucinous cystic neoplasm on cytology (neoplastic mucinous cyst)* Disordered mucinous epithelial clusters with nuclear overlap and variable cytologic atypia* Distinguishing a low grade mucinous neoplasm from gastrointestinal tract contaminant (particularly gastric mucosa) can be challenging

Cytology images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasipmn_wiley05.png)](https://acsjournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/cncy.21344#cncy21344-fig-0002)

Low grade epithelial atypia

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasipmn_wiley06.png)](https://acsjournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/cncy.21344#cncy21344-fig-0003)

High grade epithelial atypia with necrotic debris

Positive stains

* General ductal markers are positive, including [CK7](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck7.html), [CK19](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck19.html), [CA 19-9](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsca19-9.html), [B72.3](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsb723.html) and [CEA](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainscea.html)* Subtypes show various mucin glycoprotein (MUC) expression (as [below](https://pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasipmn.html#pancreasipmnnegativestainsRB)):
    + Gastric type IPMN: [MUC5AC](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmuc2.html)+, [MUC6](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmuc2.html) variable ([Am J Surg Pathol 2006;30:1561](17122512), [Mod Pathol 2016;29:977](27198568))+ Intestinal type IPMN: [MUC2](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmuc2.html)+, [CDX2](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainscdx2.html)+, [MUC5AC](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmuc2.html)+; similar staining pattern for associated invasive colloid carcinoma ([Mod Pathol 2016;29:977](27198568))+ Pancreaticobiliary type IPMN: [MUC1](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsema.html)+, [MUC6](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmuc2.html)+, [MUC5AC](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmuc2.html)+; similar staining pattern for associated invasive ductal adenocarcinoma ([Am J Surg Pathol 2006;30:1561](17122512), [Mod Pathol 2016;29:977](27198568))

Negative stains

* Gastric type IPMN: [MUC1](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsema.html)-, [MUC2](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmuc2.html)- ([Am J Surg Pathol 2006;30:1561](17122512), [Mod Pathol 2016;29:977](27198568))* Intestinal type IPMN: [MUC1](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsema.html)-; similar staining pattern for associated invasive colloid carcinoma ([Mod Pathol 2016;29:977](27198568))* Pancreaticobiliary type IPMN: [MUC2](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmuc2.html)-; similar staining pattern for associated invasive ductal adenocarcinoma ([Am J Surg Pathol 2010;34:364](20139757), [Mod Pathol 2016;29:977](27198568))

Molecular / cytogenetics description

* *KRAS*, *GNAS* and *RNF43* mutations seen in decreasing frequency in noninvasive IPMNs and IPMNs with an associated invasive carcinoma ([J Am Coll Surg 2015;220:845](25840541))* *GNAS* mutations more commonly associated with IPMNs, which harbor an invasive colloid carcinoma* *KRAS* mutations more commonly associated with IPMNs, which harbor an invasive tubular (ductal) adenocarcinoma* With increasing grades of dysplasia, increased mutations in *KRAS*, *TP53*, *CDKN2A* (p16); also hypermethylation and reduced BRG1 protein ([Hum Pathol 2012;43:585](21940037))* Loss of programmed cell death 4 (PDCD4) and CD24 expression associated with tumor progression and proliferation ([Hum Pathol 2010;41:1507](20656320), [Hum Pathol 2010;41:1466](20619441))* Cyst fluid shows mutations in *KRAS2* and *GNAS*

Sample pathology report

* Pancreas, small bowel and stomach, pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple resection):
  + Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN), low grade, gastric phenotype, branch duct type, 3.0 cm (see comment)+ Negative for high grade dysplasia or malignancy.+ Margins are negative for IPMN.+ 23 lymph nodes with no significant histologic abnormality.+ Comment: The entire cyst is submitted for histologic examination.

Differential diagnosis

* [Intraductal oncocytic papillary neoplasm](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasiopn.html):
  + Lined by oncocytic cells with complex growth patterns and arborizing papillae+ Distinct molecular pathway with *ARHGAP26*, *ASXL1*, *EPHA8* and *ERBB4* genetic alterations ([Mod Pathol 2016;29:1058](27282351))+ *DNAJB1-PRKACA* fusions ([Mod Pathol 2020;33:648](31676785))+ [MUC1](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsema.html)+, [MUC6](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmuc2.html)+* [Intraductal tubulopapillary neoplasm](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasitpn.html):
    + Recently recognized subtype with potential origin from peribiliary cysts ([Am J Surg Pathol 2009;33:1164](19440145))+ Confluent epithelial cells with tubular and papillary architectural patterns and usually high grade dysplasia+ Necrotic foci, more solid growth without visible mucin or scanty cytoplasmic mucin, no *KRAS2* gene mutations+ [MUC1](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsema.html)+, [MUC2](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmuc2.html)-, [MUC6](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmuc2.html)+* [Mucinous cystic neoplasm](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasmcn.html):
      + Epithelial mucinous lining with ovarian type stroma+ No communication to pancreatic ductal system* [Pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreaspanin.html):
        + Only detectable microscopically+ No mass lesion, unlike IPMN+ Almost always has gastric foveolar differentiation* [Simple mucinous cyst](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasmucnoncyst.html):
          + Cyst > 1 cm with flat (not papillary) gastric mucinous lining and no significant atypia ([Am J Surg Pathol 2015;39:1730](26559377), [Am J Surg Pathol 2017;41:121](27740966))* **Retention cyst**:
            + Cyst > 1 cm with flat (not papillary) ductal lining and no significant atypia in a background of obstruction ([Am J Surg Pathol 2015;39:1730](26559377))

Additional references

* [Bosman: WHO Classification of Tumours of the Digestive System, 4th Edition, 2010](http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/9283224329/pathologyoutl-20), [WHO Classification of Tumours Editorial Board: Digestive System Tumours, 5th Edition, 2019](http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/9283244990/pathologyoutl-20)
